docs.snippet: Many of the video games that the N.R.A. blamed for the Newtown, Conn., shootings have marketing relationships with the makers of firearms and ammunition.
docs.lead_paragraph: Many of the video games that the N.R.A. blamed for the Newtown, Conn., shootings have marketing relationships with the makers of firearms and ammunition.
docs.abstract: Editorial notes that many video games that National Rifle Assn blames for Newtown, Conn, shootings have marketing relationships with makers of firearms and ammunition; asserts that these troubling relationships expose NRA's disingenuous strategy of deflecting blame while denying that the association, which is the most influential opponent of sensible gun-control policies, bears any responsibility for the growing number of massacres like Newtown.

docs.snippet: Dell shareholders want an appraisal of the founder’s takeover bid for the company. But he wants documents, lots of them.
docs.lead_paragraph: Dell shareholders want an appraisal of the founder’s takeover bid for the company. But he wants documents, lots of them.
docs.abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Fair Game column observes that Dell shareholders want an appraisal of founder Michael S Dell's $25 billion takeover bid for company; points out he wants lots of documents, which could hold up case longer than usual; contends Dell's maneuver may discourage shareholders in future appraisal cases from exercising their rights.

docs.snippet: With the release of Microsoft's Xbox video game console on Nov. 15 and Nintendo's GameCube three days later, the market for video game consoles is poised for a shift, but it may not be much of one.     A research report released last month by Cahners...
docs.lead_paragraph: With the release of Microsoft's Xbox video game console on Nov. 15 and Nintendo's GameCube three days later, the market for video game consoles is poised for a shift, but it may not be much of one. A research report released last month by Cahners In-Stat Group says that Sony, the current market leader with its PlayStation console, will sell 21 million consoles in 2002, compared with 6 million for Nintendo and 2.5 million for Microsoft.
docs.abstract: Cahners In-Stat Group predicts 21 million video gaming consoles will be sold by Sony in 2002, 6 million by Nintendo and 2.5 million by Microsoft; chart (S)

headline.kicker: MOST WANTED: DRILLING DOWN/VIDEO GAME CONSOLES

docs.snippet: For 111 years, Stanford and Cal, which play on Saturday, have battled for supremacy on the football field. Still, there is more than one way to compete.
docs.lead_paragraph: For 111 years, Stanford and Cal, which play on Saturday, have battled for supremacy on the football field. Still, there is more than one way to compete.

headline.main: A Cal-Stanford Score, Off the Field
headline.print_headline: A Cal-Stanford Score, Off the Field

docs.snippet: ASKED which of four American artists painted ''Nighthawks,'' an ''ode to big-city loneliness,'' a contestant on ''Russian Roulette'' guesses Andrew Wyeth. (As anybody who has ever walked through the front door of the Whitney knows, it was Edward...
docs.lead_paragraph: ASKED which of four American artists painted ''Nighthawks,'' an ''ode to big-city loneliness,'' a contestant on ''Russian Roulette'' guesses Andrew Wyeth. (As anybody who has ever walked through the front door of the Whitney knows, it was Edward Hopper.) On ''Dog Eat Dog,'' a man asked to name the largest island in the Mediterranean Sea answers, ''Hawaii.'' (Uh, no. It's Sicily.) The television game show and its special pleasures -- playing along and feeling smart when other people are stupid -- lives. But don't expect GSN, formerly the Game Show Network, to put all its chips in one pot. Even before the nearly 10-year-old network officially changed its name in March, it had been busily redefining itself as the channel for games, not game shows. And ''games'' are broadly defined.
docs.abstract: Game Show Network offers new take on television mainstay to try to draw younger audience; reruns of popoular old game shows are also on schedule; photos (M)

headline.main: In Search Of Youth: Game Show Makeovers

docs.snippet: With vast resources from stolen financial information, cyberattackers are winning a technology arms race.

headline.print_headline: Thieves Winning Online War, Maybe Even in Your Computer

docs.snippet: LEAD: Charles N. Mathewson, a successful investor from California, was at a golf tournament here six years ago when he noticed people lined up to play a video poker game at the Reno Hilton. Intrigued, he checked the machines for the name of the...
docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: Charles N. Mathewson, a successful investor from California, was at a golf tournament here six years ago when he noticed people lined up to play a video poker game at the Reno Hilton. Intrigued, he checked the machines for the name of the manufacturer and bought some stock in the company, International Game Technology.

byline.original: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times
